script.speaker: Alex
script.text: Dude, I' ve been meaning to ask you- where's my Xbox game?

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: Oh, uh, I think I lent it to Mike... I don't know, it's been a while.

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: A while? You borrowed it from me four months ago. Consideration, man. Some people actually buy their own stuff.

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: Come on, I said I was sorry. I've just been really busy, I didn't forget. I'll try to get it back to you this weekend, but don't be that guy who never lends anything to anyone, 'cause that's not how friends work.

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: That's not even the point, Thomas. It's about being considerate. If you're gonna borrow something from me, at least return it on time or let me know what's going on. Simple social etiquette, you know?

script.speaker: Thomas
script.text: Okay, I get it, I'll try to do better. But don't get all high and mighty on me, Alex. As friends, can't we just work this out without all the drama?

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Rigoberto, I need to talk to you about something. I saw the way you were looking at your cousin, Samantha, at the family reunion last weekend...

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: What are you talking about, Meredith? I was just being friendly.

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Friendly? Rigoberto, you're practically a young man now, and I know how these things can be misinterpreted. I just want you to be careful, that's all...

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: You're being dramatic, Meredith. I can take care of myself. - And besides, you're always saying I should be more social, now you're complaining when I am?

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Rigoberto, that's not what I meant. I just don't want you to get hurt or get the wrong idea about someone. And as your grandmother, it's my job to worry about these things.

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: You're not my mom, Meredith. I know you're trying to look out for me, but sometimes you just have to trust me, okay?

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Fine, Rigoberto. Just be careful, that's all I'm saying...

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: I'm so frustrated with this writing assignment. I want to write something that's actually creative, but the teacher just keeps saying I need to stick to the prompts.

script.speaker: Hai
script.text: Taylor, you know why she's saying that. You've been experimenting with your own style, and it's not always -

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: -not always what? Not always good enough? Because I feel like I'm just regurgitating the same old stories everyone else writes. Where's the imagination in that?

script.speaker: Hai
script.text: Imagination is one thing, but discipline is also important. Remember that time you read me that passage from 'Alice in Wonderland'? That's some crazy imagination right there, but Lewis Carroll still managed to make it coherent.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Yeah, but he was a genius. I'm just trying to get a decent grade here. And it's not like I'm not following any rules. I just want to take some risks and try new things. Like, have you ever noticed how much Tolkien's world-building influenced the fantasy genre? That's what I want to do - create something entirely new.

script.speaker: Hai
script.text: I understand where you're coming from, but sometimes you need to learn the rules before you can break them. Why don't we sit down and go over the assignment together? See if we can't find a way to make it more... imaginative?

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Fine... But it's not just about the assignment. It's about the whole creative process. I feel like I'm being stifled by all these rules and expectations. I just wish people would trust me to come up with something good on my own.

script.speaker: Hai
script.text: Taylor, I trust you more than anyone. I just want to see you succeed, and sometimes that means playing by the rules. But I'm also willing to listen to your ideas and help you find a way to make them work.

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Hey, Maribel, I noticed you've been basically running a full-on art studio out of your garage. I'm starting to think it's more than a hobby.

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: Oh, yeah... I guess I have been spending a lot of time on it lately. But it's just something I do to unwind, you know?

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Unwind? You're out there until midnight most nights. I've seen you through the fence, with, like, paint everywhere and weird music blasting. You're definitely doing something more than unwinding. Do you ever think maybe this is something you could actually make a career out of?

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: -Look, Meredith, as a neighbor, I appreciate your concern, but- I think I know what I'm doing. This isn't some midlife crisis or something; it's just what I enjoy doing in my free time.

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Free time? I've seen you take on, like, three or four different art projects at once. That's a lot of work. And you know, I've been thinking, have you ever taken a step back to, like, really reflect on why you're doing all this? Is it just for the sake of being creative, or is it something more?

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: Honestly... I don't know, okay? Maybe I'm just trying to prove to myself that I can do it. Maybe I'm trying to show everyone else that I can do it too. You don't have to understand it, Meredith. It's basically none of your business.

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Fine, but as your neighbor, it is my business when the noise is keeping me awake or the smell of paint is drifting into my yard. I'm just saying, maybe you should think about setting some boundaries for yourself. Maybe consider taking some classes or- I don't know, just to get a better sense of what you're doing.

script.speaker: Maribel
script.text: I'll think about it, okay? Now if you'll excuse me, I have work to do. I have a project due soon, and I'm the only one who can finish it on time...

script.speaker: Meredith
script.text: Fine, I'll let you get back to it... just try to keep the noise down, okay?

script.speaker: Lucy
script.text: Linda, where've you been? I haven't seen you all week.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: I was out, just catching up with some friends... You know, stuff.

script.speaker: Lucy
script.text: You've been doing that a lot lately. Remember when Mom would always say we should spend quality time together as sisters?

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: -Oh, come on, Lucy. Mom said that 'cause we used to fight all the time when we were kids. Things change, we're adults now...

script.speaker: Lucy
script.text: Exactly, and as adults, I think we should try to hang out more often, like we used to. You're not even answering my calls lately.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: Sorry, I forgot to call you back. I've just been really busy with work...

script.speaker: Lucy
script.text: Work? Really? Or is it that new guy you're seeing? I feel like you're abandoning our friendship for him.

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: That's not true... He's just someone I'm dating. Don't be like that.

script.speaker: Lucy
script.text: I'm 'like that' because I care about our sisterly bond and I feel like you're drifting away...

script.speaker: Linda
script.text: Whatever, Lucy. Fine, we'll hang out soon...

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: I'm telling you, Rich, dad's sense of humor is contagious. He can make anyone laugh with that ridiculous face of his

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: - I know, I know, but that time he tried to make us laugh at grandma's birthday by doing that awkward chicken dance, it was more awkward than funny

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: Come on, that was hilarious. I have the video to prove it, you're just being a grump. Remember that time we couldn't stop laughing and mom scolded us for being too loud?

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: Osvaldo, that was like 20 years ago. I think it's time to move on from those memories, bro

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: Why, what's wrong with reminiscing? It's not like I'm still living in the past. Although, I do think dad was funnier back then. I mean, his jokes aren't as sharp as they used to be

script.speaker: Richard
script.text: I don't know, man, maybe I'm just not paying attention to his jokes anymore. Anyway, look, I gotta go. I have some stuff to take care of

script.speaker: Osvaldo
script.text: Alright, alright. But don't think you're getting off that easily. I'll show you the video later and you can relive the magic of dad's chicken dance

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Come on, Mei, you can't be serious about changing Alex's character like that? I spent months developing his backstory.

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: I'm not asking to rewrite the whole script, just tweak his motivations a bit -

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: A bit? You want to make him a completely different person. Remember how Mom always said we had to work together, and Dad -

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: -yeah, yeah, I know, our parents always said that. But honestly, Taylor, you're being really inflexible. It's just a character change, it's not like -

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Inflexible? You're the one who's always barging in and changing everything without talking to me first. Like that time in high school when you 'accidentally' deleted my essay draft -

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Oh, that was one time, and I apologized for it. But this script...I think my ideas are really good, and you're just not listening. Can we at least discuss this without bringing up our childhood?

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Fine, but can you at least try to see it from my perspective? I'm not just some stubborn brother who refuses to change; I have a vision for this story. And I think your changes will ruin it.

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: I am trying, Taylor. And I think my changes will actually improve it. You're just too close to the material right now. We should take a break and revisit this later when you're not so... attached.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Attached? You're one to talk, Miss 'I-just-want-to-make-one-little-change' -

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Listen Mariela, I don't understand why you're still delaying getting married. You're already 28, and it's time you start thinking about settling down.

script.speaker: Mariela
script.text: Aunt Mei, I-... I mean, I don't see what the rush is. I'm not even financially independent yet.

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: - Financial independence won't come until you have a stable partner, someone to support you. And your parents are getting worried too.

script.speaker: Mariela
script.text: I know that, but I want to achieve that on my own. Not because I have to rely on someone else. And besides, Mom and Dad just want me to be happy, right?

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Of course, they do, but they also want to see you secure and stable. Your future plans are all over the place, Mariela. When are you going to focus on your career and find someone to spend the rest of your life with?

script.speaker: Mariela
script.text: Aunt Mei, you don't understand... things are different now. I can have a career and travel without needing to be married. And I'm not even sure if I want kids yet...

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Not sure if you want kids? What kind of talk is that? You're a part of this family, and family is about legacy and passing it down. Your parents will be disappointed if you don't give them grandchildren.

script.speaker: Mariela
script.text: I know that, but I have my own dreams and aspirations, and I don't want to rush into anything just to make everyone happy.

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: I'm telling you, Trang, that rumor about the Joneses is totally true.

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: What are you talking about? You're not going to start spreading gossip again, are you? I swear, I don't know how you get this stuff.

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: It's not gossip - my cousin works with their son, and she told me the whole story about the family secret...

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: - no, no, no. Don't even think about sharing that. You know how much I hate when people air their dirty laundry in public. Journalistic ethics, Emma, don't you remember that from our high school newspaper?

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: Journalistic ethics? Come on, Trang, this has nothing to do with journalism. It's just us, neighbors catching up.

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: Just us? You're the one who always wants to share the 'exclusive scoop' at our neighborhood potlucks. I don't know why you can't just keep some things to yourself.

script.speaker: Emma
script.text: I'm just trying to share the news, Trang. Don't be so uptight. And by the way, have you paid the HOA fees yet? The letter said it's overdue...

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: - Ugh, don't change the subject, Emma. And yes, I paid the fees last week. You're not exactly the neighborhood treasurer, you know?

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: Aunt Taylor, I don't know why mom's expecting me to attend the family reunion this weekend. I just got back from college and I'm exhausted...

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: - Come on Michael, it's been a year since we've all seen you. You can't just skip it, your cousins are really looking forward to catching up with you

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: But that's just it, I don't really keep in touch with them and I don't feel like making small talk all day. Plus, isn't this what you're always saying? That I should focus on my own relationships and friendships, rather than just doing things out of obligation?

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: That's different, Michael. Your family is important, and just because you're not close to your cousins now doesn't mean you can't try to reconnect. Trust me, when you get older you'll regret not making the effort

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: But what about your relationship with mom? You guys always seem so... strained. Is that really something I want to model in my own life?

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Michael, that's not fair. Your mother and I have a complicated history, but that doesn't mean I don't care about her or the rest of the family. And just because I've had disagreements with your mom doesn't mean I don't value family relationships

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: I guess I just wish we could all be more honest with each other about what we really want and expect from each other, instead of just going through the motions out of obligation

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: I understand what you're saying, Michael, but sometimes going through the motions is what keeps families together

script.speaker: Quoc
script.text: Hey, Alex, I need to talk to you about the fence between our yards. I know it's been an issue for a while-

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: What about it? You're not still mad about the dog getting loose?

script.speaker: Quoc
script.text: No, that's not it. It's just, I've been noticing that the fence is getting really worn out, and I think we should split the cost to replace it. It's only fair, since we both use it-

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: -I don't know, Quoc. As neighbors, I value our relationship, but I'm going through a tough time financially. My mom's been sick, and I've been racking up medical bills-

script.speaker: Quoc
script.text: Oh, I'm so sorry to hear that. I didn't know... Look, let's put the fence on hold for now. How's your mom doing? Is there anything I can do to help?

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: Thanks for offering, Quoc. She's... it's been tough. Just taking care of her and trying to keep my head above water. Honestly, your support means a lot. Just knowing I have someone to talk to... Sometimes I feel like I'm all alone in this.

script.speaker: Quoc
script.text: You're not alone, Alex. We're neighbors, but we're also friends, right? I'm here for you. And we can always figure out the fence later. Family's more important-

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: Thanks, Quoc... that means a lot coming from you. Yeah, let's just focus on that for now.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Tyrone, I'm trying to practice my violin, could you please keep it down? Some of us are trying to be creative in our own homes.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Come on, Jordan, I'm just having a gathering of like-minded individuals - it's a happening, man. We're exploring the boundaries of art and self-expression.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I'm not stopping you from being... eccentric. Just maybe not at 3 am on a Tuesday?

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: You're not understanding the concept of spontaneity - that's what stifles creativity. Maybe you should try letting go and embracing the chaos, my friend.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I'm just trying to have a quiet night, Tyrone. We can catch up tomorrow, I promise.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: You know, Jordan, I've been thinking... as neighbors, we should be more supportive of each other's pursuits. That's what community is all about, right?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: - Tyrone, I appreciate that, but -

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: No, no, hear me out. I've been self-reflecting, and I think I can help you find your true artistic voice. You're just not tapping into it yet.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Tyrone, I appreciate the offer, but I think I'll manage. Just please... keep it down.

script.speaker: Kimberly
script.text: Tameka I'm starting to think you're never going to give back my favorite sweater

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Oh I'm so sorry - I totally forgot I even had it. It's been hanging in my closet since our movie night last week

script.speaker: Kimberly
script.text: Last week? Come on, Tameka - we've been seeing each other for a month now, I know you're busy but some consideration would be nice

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: - it's just a sweater... fine. I'll bring it over tomorrow. But you have to promise not to get upset whenever I borrow something - it's not a big deal to me

script.speaker: Kimberly
script.text: it's not just about the sweater. It's about respect... and trust. Little things like this can either make or break a relationship. My sister and her boyfriend are always fighting about this stuff

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: your sister's relationship is not our relationship, babe. can we please not compare our relationship to others? it's not fair... and, I love that you care, but I'm really not used to people keeping tabs on what I borrow

script.speaker: Kimberly
script.text: I'm not keeping tabs - I just want to know that you value my stuff the way I value yours... and our relationship. we've talked about moving in together soon, so I think it's a big deal

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: Sofia, we need to talk about your plans for college. You're not even looking at schools in-state anymore, what's going on?

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: Dad, come on, I've told you, I want to experience something new... I don't know, get out of this town for a while... maybe New York or California... And, honestly, I don't know why you care so much, you're always talking about how I should be independent.

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: - Sofia, independence doesn't mean not considering your family at all. Your mother and I did a lot for you, and... it's just, people will think you're abandoning us if you go that far away. Not to mention, it's expensive... You know your grandmother always says 'la familia es lo primero'.

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: That's not fair, Dad... grandma says that because she wants us to stick together, not because she wants me to live in this tiny town forever... And, by the way, people can think whatever they want, I'm not going to make my life decisions based on what the neighbors say... You always taught me to be strong, and that's what I'm doing.

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: Being strong doesn't mean not listening to your parents, Sofia... You're my daughter, and I know what's best for you. You're not thinking about the future, you're thinking about some romantic idea of freedom.

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: You don't know what's best for me... and, I am thinking about the future, that's exactly why I want to leave... You're not even trying to understand me... You just want me to do what you want, like always.

script.speaker: Diego
script.text: Sofia, that's not true... I'm just worried, okay? I don't want you to make a decision you'll regret... Can we at least talk about this some more, maybe your mom can-...

script.speaker: Sofia
script.text: Whatever, Dad... We'll talk about it later... Can I go now?

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Hey, Deandre, can I talk to you about the team project we're working on?

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: What's up? I thought we were good for the deadline

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: We are, but I feel like I'm doing most of the work. I mean, you're the team lead, but I've been handling all the delegation and follow-ups... it's kinda unfair, don't you think?

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Hold up, I don't think that's entirely true -

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: No, hear me out. We're friends, and I know we can work well together, but as friends, I value our collaboration and social dynamics, you know? We should be on the same page

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Okay, fine... but what specific tasks do you think I'm not pulling my weight on?

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Well, like last week's meeting - you didn't send out the minutes or follow up with Rachel on her part of the project... and the week before, you didn't contribute much to the brainstorming session... I just feel like I'm picking up the slack

script.speaker: Deandre
script.text: Alright, alright, I get it... I've been slacking a bit... sorry, Trinh. But as friends, can we also acknowledge that sometimes we help each other out, right? You've had my back before, and I'll do the same

script.speaker: Trinh
script.text: Exactly, that's what friends are for... but in this case, let's get back on track and figure out how to share the workload more evenly, okay?

script.speaker: David
script.text: You know I've been thinking - and I'm not saying this has anything to do with you, but... have you ever felt like the news desk is more about ratings than actual journalism?

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Well, that's not exactly a new concern, David... -

script.speaker: David
script.text: No, no, hear me out. It's not just that. It's... I feel like we're starting to sensationalize things just to get clicks. I'm not sure I'm comfortable with that.

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: Honestly, David, I've been a journalist for years, and this is just the way the game is played. You're not naive, you know this. And to be frank, I'm a bit worried - are you losing your edge? We need you sharp for the Smith investigation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: My edge? You think this is about my edge? It's about integrity, Mei. And I know I'm not the only one who's starting to question our priorities... By the way, did you see the piece John wrote on the city council scandal? That was some actual journalism right there.

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: David, David, David... you're getting all worked up over nothing. John's piece was great, but come on, we can't all be chasing Pulitzers. And as for priorities, I think our editor would disagree with you on that. - Anyway, don't you have that meeting with the source in an hour?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yeah... yeah, I do. I guess I just wish we could... I dunno, find a better balance or something. This job used to mean something to me, you know? And I don't want to lose that... and I especially don't want to lose it because of some ratings chase. Speaking of which, how was your day, anyway? Anything exciting happen?

script.speaker: Mei
script.text: It was fine... just fine. Look, David, I understand where you're coming from, but we can talk about this later, okay? I have some work to finish before dinner. And by the way, don't forget we have that dinner date with my sister tonight.

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: I don't think you should be going to that concert tonight, Alex. It's getting late and you have school tomorrow.

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: Aww, come on dad... I'm almost 16... All my friends are going and it's a big deal... -

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: -I've talked to your mom about this, Alex. We're not comfortable with you going out that late on a school night. You know the rules. Curfew is 10, and you can't just break it whenever you feel like it.

script.speaker: Alex
script.text: But... that's not faaaaair... Other parents don't care what time their kids get home... I'm responsible, I can handle it... and what's with you and mom always agreeing on everything? Can't you just see things from my perspective for once?

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: Alex, your mom and I discuss things because we're your parents, and it's our job to make decisions for your well-being. And as for being responsible, you're still in school, and you need to prioritize that. You can go to concerts during the summer when you don't have school the next day. That's the deal. No arguing.

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: Mom, why do I have to make my own breakfast again? You never used to make me do this when I was younger.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: Heriberto, sweetie, you're getting older, you need to start being more independent. And besides, I have to get ready for work. Your father left early this morning, and I have to cover his shift -

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: But that's not fair, you're always saying I have to be more responsible, but you never give me any real responsibilities. I'm the one who's always stuck with cleaning my room and doing the dishes... And by the way, can't you just talk to dad about the whole work thing? It's always affecting us, and I feel like we never get to spend any time together as a family.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: - Heriberto, stop, just... stop. I don't have time for this right now. Your father and I will discuss this later, but for now, you need to get ready for school, and I need to get to work. Just make some toast or something, okay?

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: Fine... But this conversation isn't over.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: Heriberto, just... go to school, and we'll talk later, I promise.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: Latonya, how's it going? I feel like I haven't seen you in ages. You always seem so stressed lately...

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: I'm good, Aunt Lucia. Just work stuff. We've got a lot on our plate right now. I've been putting in like 12, 13 hour days.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: I can imagine. Look, I was thinking, maybe we could grab dinner this weekend? I heard there's a new brunch place downtown.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: Uh, I don't know, Aunt Lucia. I've got a lot going on. Plus, to be honest, I've been drinking a bit too much lately... and I know you're always on my case about that.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: Latonya, honey, I'm not trying to be on your case. I just don't want to see you burning out. And the drinking's not helping. You're better than that.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: -Aunt Lucia, come on, it's not a big deal... I just need something to unwind. You know, performance anxiety at work's been killing me. I feel like one wrong move and I'm done.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: I understand that, but there are better ways to unwind. Remember when you were in college and you used to love painting? You should take that up again. It would be good for you.

script.speaker: Latonya
script.text: Aunt Lucia, that's not going to pay my bills. And to be honest, I'm just not feeling it right now. I'll try to cut back on the drinking, okay?

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: Okay, deal. But just so you know, I'm here for you. If you need someone to talk to or just need some space... my door's always open.

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: Sandra, what's up with the state of the kitchen? You left a huge mess after making breakfast this morning...

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: Oh, for Pete's sake, Tuan, it's just a few dishes. You're being super uptight today. What's wrong?

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: What's wrong is that mom and dad are coming over tonight and they're going to see this disaster. And by the way, I'm not uptight, I just don't want to deal with a ton of extra cleaning because you can't be bothered to put things away...

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: That's so unfair - you're one to talk about being lazy. I do my fair share of chores around here. Besides, mom and dad won't care, they've seen the kitchen in way worse states when we were kids...

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: That's exactly my point - we're not kids anymore, Sandra. We're adults trying to be professional and run a household together. Speaking of which, I've been really busy with work lately, and I don't appreciate you scheduling meetings for me without checking with me first...

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: I was just trying to help... I didn't think it was a big deal. Fine, don't schedule anything for me either, then. See if I care... Anyway, mom's going to freak when she sees my new tattoo. - You didn't tell her, did you?

script.speaker: Tuan
script.text: No... I didn't tell her. And maybe you should've thought about that before getting it. I'm going to go clean up the kitchen before I lose my mind...

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: Thanks, bro... I guess

script.speaker: Daniel
script.text: I'm telling you, Yesenia, it's getting crazy out there - layoffs everywhere. People are panicking. You're lucky to have that stable government job.

script.speaker: Yesenia
script.text: Lucky - that's not the word I'd use. It's boring, Daniel, it's suffocating. I'm just going through the motions every day.

script.speaker: Daniel
script.text: Come on, don't be dramatic, sis. At least you've got benefits and a 401k. I'm struggling to find something with actual stability... you know, something mom and dad would be proud of.

script.speaker: Yesenia
script.text: - exactly, that's what I'm trying to get away from - that pressure from mom and dad to be this perfect, stable daughter. I want to be my own person, not just some cog in a bureaucratic machine.

script.speaker: Daniel
script.text: That's easy for you to say, you've always been the rebellious one, but someone's gotta pay the bills. And honestly, I don't get why you're suddenly so opposed to the whole 'stable job' thing - it's not like you're exactly living the bohemian dream or anything...

script.speaker: Yesenia
script.text: That's not the point, Daniel. It's about identity - what am I, really? Not just some title or some job description. And another thing, what's with your sudden obsession with stability? You're starting to sound like dad...

script.speaker: Daniel
script.text: - well, excuse me for wanting some semblance of security in my life... considering we grew up with, you know, pretty much the opposite.

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: Hey, do you want some scrambled eggs? I was thinking of making breakfast

script.speaker: Marisol
script.text: - No, no, that's ok, I'll just have some coffee. I have a big meeting today and I'm kind of nervous about it

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: What's the meeting about? I thought you said your boss was going to go easy on you since you're still new

script.speaker: Marisol
script.text: Yeah, I did, but apparently, there's been some issues with the project timeline and I'm getting pulled into it... I don't know, it's just really frustrating

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: I'm sure you'll handle it fine. You're always so on top of things. I mean, we've been talking about our ideas for that business plan for months now, and you're always so organized

script.speaker: Marisol
script.text: That's different, Michael. This is a real job with real expectations. I don't want to mess it up... And I thought we agreed to table the business plan talk for now

script.speaker: Michael
script.text: - Table it? I thought we were just getting started. I've been doing some research and I think I found a really promising opportunity for us

script.speaker: Marisol
script.text: Later, Michael. Not now. I have to go get ready for this meeting... And can we please just focus on supporting each other for now, rather than always talking about our future plans?

script.speaker: Charles
script.text: You know, I've been thinking... we've been friends for a pretty long time, right? And I'm starting to feel like we've drifted apart. We don't hang out as much as we used to, and when we do, it's always something fancy, not just us grabbing burgers and talking about our lives.

script.speaker: Jennifer
script.text: I know what you mean... life gets busy, and my work schedule has been crazy lately. But that's not the only reason, is it? You've been distant, too. Remember that time we were supposed to go hiking, and you just canceled on me?

script.speaker: Charles
script.text: Yeah, I'm sorry about that. I just wasn't feeling it that day. And to be honest, I've been feeling really overwhelmed with our group of friends lately. Everyone's moving forward in their lives â€“ getting married, having kids... I feel like we're the only ones stuck in limbo.

script.speaker: Jennifer
script.text: Stuck in limbo? What are you talking about? You're the one who's always been so focused on your career. And I'm happy for you, but sometimes I feel like you're pushing me to be more competitive, more driven... I like my life the way it is.

script.speaker: Charles
script.text: - No, no, that's not what I meant. I just feel like we used to be on the same page, you know? And now it feels like we're just going through the motions of being friends. We don't have those deep conversations like we used to.

script.speaker: Jennifer
script.text: You're right... I have been feeling that way too. But maybe it's not about going back to how things were, maybe it's about finding a new normal for our friendship.

script.speaker: Charles
script.text: A new normal? I don't know... I feel like we need to make an effort to reconnect, to be more intentional about our friendship.

script.speaker: Jennifer
script.text: I'm willing to try, but we need to meet each other halfway. Can we start by grabbing those burgers and talking about our lives... like you said?

script.speaker: Alejandra
script.text: Mama, I'm trying to write this short story for class, but I have no idea what to write about. It's like, I'm just staring at a blank page.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: You know, when I was in school... -

script.speaker: Alejandra
script.text: Mama, you're not listening. I don't want to hear about when you were in school. I need help now.

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: Fine, fine. What's the assignment? Maybe I can help you brainstorm.

script.speaker: Alejandra
script.text: It's just... we have to write something that inspires us. But everything I think of seems so boring. And Abuela always says I'm creative, but I don't feel like it right now...

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: Well, you know what they say: 'art is in the eye of the beholder.' Maybe you're just putting too much pressure on yourself. Why don't you take a break and go for a walk? Sometimes clearing your head helps.

script.speaker: Alejandra
script.text: But Mama, I don't have time for a walk. The deadline is tomorrow and I still have to finish my math homework... You always say I should be responsible and manage my time, but now you're telling me to just take a break?

script.speaker: Lucia
script.text: Alejandra, I'm trying to help. As your mother, it's my job to give you advice, and right now, I think taking a break would be good for you. And by the way, your Abuela always says you're creative because she believes in you, and so do I.

script.speaker: Hieu
script.text: I feel like you're always asking what I'm doing, where I'm going... it's a bit much, isn't it? I mean, we've only been seeing each other for a few months.

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: Well, I just like to know what's going on in your life, that's all. Is that a problem?

script.speaker: Hieu
script.text: Not a problem, per se... but I do value my independence. I'm not used to having to check in with someone all the time.

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: I'm just trying to be a good partner, I guess. My friends all seem to know what their boyfriends are up to at all times... I feel like I'm missing out or something.

script.speaker: Hieu
script.text: You're comparing our relationship to your friends'? That's not fair. We're not them. And besides, I thought we were doing okay... I mean, we're still figuring things out.

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: -figuring things out? Hieu, we're not in high school anymore. At some point we need to think about the future... you know, long-term plans, moving in together... stuff like that.

script.speaker: Hieu
script.text: Whoa, slow down. I'm not saying I don't see a future with you, but... can't we just take things one step at a time? You're making me feel like you're rushing me into something I'm not ready for.

script.speaker: Patricia
script.text: I... I just want to know where we stand, I guess. Is that too much to ask?

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Dude, mom's gonna kill you if you don't show up to Aunt Karen's birthday dinner tomorrow. You promised you'd be there.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: I don't know, Ty... I was thinking of maybe just meeting up with some friends instead. We haven't hung out in ages.

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Friends? You mean that new crew you've been running with? Listen, I don't think mom's gonna care about your social life right now. Family commitments come first.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: Come on, Ty, you're not exactly the poster child for family obligations. Remember that time you skipped grandma's anniversary party to go to that music festival?

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: That was one time, okay? And it's not the same. Mom's really been stressing about this dinner and how it's gonna look to the rest of the family if you don't show up. You're gonna make it awkward for everyone.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: - And maybe I'm just tired of always being expected to put family first, you know? It feels like I'm always sacrificing my own stuff for mom's sake. Can't I just have some space?

script.speaker: Tyrone
script.text: Taylor, it's not like that. This is just one dinner. It's not gonna kill you to put on a smile and pretend to care for a few hours. It's for mom, and for our family's sake.

script.speaker: Taylor
script.text: I don't know, Ty... maybe I just need some time to figure some stuff out. Can you just cover for me and tell mom something?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Hey Heriberto, I saw that job posting for the community center on your door the other day - how's the interview process going?

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: - Yeah, it's going all right, I guess. I really like the idea of working there, it's close to home...

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Absolutely, that's amazing. I mean I barely see you around here as it is, but if you worked at the community center, we'd pretty much never see each other

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: Ha, that's true. But, honestly, I need something with more career opportunities

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Career opportunities, huh? What do you mean? I thought the job at the community center was pretty great for someone who wants to help out around here... like us neighbors, you know, we like that kind of stuff

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: Yeah, I appreciate that, Jordan, but I really need something that's gonna set me up in the long run. Like, I've been working on my masters and I want something that's gonna give me more professional relationships, you know?

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Oh, ok, so you're looking for something more like... networking... stuff. I see what you mean

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: - Exactly. I mean, I love the idea of working at the community center, but it's just not going to open up the same doors as something else might

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I get it. You know I've always thought that working at the community center would be awesome, but, I guess when you put it that way... maybe I'm just stuck in my ways or something

script.speaker: Heriberto
script.text: No, no, it's not that, Jordan. You're just really invested in this community, and that's something to be proud of. I just need to think about my own future right now

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I'm really surprised your mom agreed to host my birthday dinner at her place...considering she's always been a little...particular about her house.

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Yeah, I know, I was kinda shocked myself. But she really likes you, Jordan, and -

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: - and I appreciate that, but I don't want to put her out. I feel like we could've just gone out to dinner or something.

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Come on, it'll be fun! We can make it a potluck, and my mom will actually relax for once...plus, you know how she loves showing off her cooking skills.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: I guess...but what if your family starts asking all those awkward questions again? You know, like 'when are you getting married' or 'when are you gonna find a real job'...

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Oh, don't worry, I've already warned my mom to keep the questions to a minimum. She promised she'd behave...and if she doesn't, we can always just change the subject or something.

script.speaker: Jordan
script.text: Alright...if you're sure it's okay with your mom, then I'm game. But if she starts getting all crazy on me, I'm blaming you.

script.speaker: Tameka
script.text: Don't worry, I'll take full responsibility if things go wrong...as friends, I think we can handle a little family drama, right?

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: Rigoberto, you're being really loud again with your lawn care, and I have a headache. Can you please keep it down? We do live next to each other after all

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: -I'm not being that loud, Sandra. You're always complaining about something

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: I'm not always complaining. You're the one who's always disturbing the peace. And by the way, your bushes are overgrown again, they're blocking part of my driveway. Can you trim them?

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: Look, Sandra, I'll try to keep it down, but as for the bushes, they're not that bad. You're just being picky

script.speaker: Sandra
script.text: I'm not being picky, I just have to deal with the consequences of your lack of maintenance. We have a homeowners association, remember? You're going to get fined again if you don't trim them. I'm trying to help you out here

script.speaker: Rigoberto
script.text: Okay, fine. I'll trim the bushes. But can we drop it now?

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: We should probably get going. My sister's still waiting for that wine glass you borrowed from her.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: Oh, I totally forgot about that, I'll grab it from the kitchen.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: It's funny, I saw your sister the other day and she didn't mention it, so I figured it wasn't a big deal...

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: -I know, but that's because she's always being nice to you. Trust me, I got a text from her like two days ago asking about it.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: Sorry... I just don't know why it's such a big deal. It's just a glass.

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: It's not just about the glass. It's about being considerate, you know? When we're at my sister's place, we borrow stuff all the time. She's always lending us things. It's only polite to return them.

script.speaker: Barbara
script.text: You're right, I guess I wasn't thinking about that... sorry. But do we really have to drop it off tonight? Can't it wait until tomorrow?

script.speaker: Trang
script.text: No, I promised my sister we'd return it tonight. Plus, we're already in the area. It's not that big of a detour. Come on, it'll only take a minute.
